title: ministry
comment: Service of a general, as well as a religious, nature. In its broadest sense ministry refers to service rendered to God or to people. Its more restricted sense refers to the official service of individuals, specially set aside by the church.

children.title: ministry, nature of
children.comment: All creatures owe their Creator a ministry of service to him and to humanity. The example and teaching of Jesus Christ illustrate this.

children.title: All human beings owe a ministry of service to God
The debt owed by the creature to the Creator
The service of the nations and their rulers
Examples of the service of rulers
The ministry of the people of God
The ministry of priests, kings and prophets in the OT
The ministry of those specially set aside by the church
Jesus Christ fulfils the OT understanding of ministry
His ministry as shepherd, teacher and prophet
NT ministry follows the pattern of Jesus Christ
In priesthood by self-sacrifice and intercession in prayer
Jesus Christ's servants can expect the same response that he received
The ministry of angels
children.precomment: Angels are both ministers to God's people and fellow-servants with them:

children.title: ministry, in the church
children.comment: The regular ministry of officially appointed or recognised ministers is a particular instance of the duty and call of all God's people.

children.title: The responsibilities of those in recognised ministry
What believers owe to those with recognised ministries

primaryrefs.comment: Despite Jesus Christ's command, Paul did not claim his rights in this matter, but supported himself as a tentmaker.

children.title: Recognised ministers should encourage the ministries of other believers

seealsos.comment: The Holy Spirit allocates gifts and enables ministries. No individual has all the gifts; ministry is shared and mutual

children.title: The motivation of ministry is mutual love
How love is expressed in mutual ministry
In prayer and confession of sin
ministry, qualifications for
children.comment: God, who calls his people to minister, also equips his people. The chief qualifications are a response to God's call, faithfulness, godliness and Christlikeness.

children.title: Qualification is by call, not gifting or achievement
God calls those who the world regards as weak or foolish
Feelings of inadequacy to God's call are common
Responding to God's call to minister
Faith, rather than natural talent or moral perfection, is required
NT ministers are recognised by call rather than their achievement

secondaryrefs.comment: The Twelve, including Peter and Judas, failed Jesus Christ at critical times.
Though greatly gifted, Paul was kept humble by his sense of unworthiness, difficulties and disappointments and his ``thorn in the flesh''

children.title: Ministry in the NT is described as service
Ministry is described in terms of its source, content or nature
Various ministries are equally linked by qualifications of character

secondaryrefs.comment: Paul's claim for his own ministry
Simon was not right with God.
The replacement apostle for Judas had to have been with Jesus Christ from the beginning.
